items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River levels continue to remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water. Further rain is expected throughout the night, which will keep the levels high, but we are not expecting to see any significant changes.
Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00am on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Warning has been issued because flooding is expected today and through the night on Thursday 28/09/2023.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Greta, River Derwent, Derwent Water lake level, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.
River levels remain high at the Lodore gauge.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

Thursday evening's tide at 23:45 on 28/09/2023 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong Southerly Force 6 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.17 m. The total forecast tide is 6.09 metres Chart Datum (3.04 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane.  The tide levels are a little elevated and will be broadly similar over the next 4 days. This may cause some impacts at each high water until Monday 02/10/2023‚ but where impacts do occur‚ they will be very minor. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping.  Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 10:00 on 29/09/2023.

As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest this evening at 09:00PM on 28/09/2023.
Flooding is possible at Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon from 08:00 PM until 10:00 PM on 28/09/2023. with the local tide level forecast to reach 1.28m.
The high tides on Friday and Saturday evening are expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
We are closely monitoring the situation remotely. We are not expecting to shut pedestrian tide gates this evening but will monitor closely.
Consider activating any property flood protection products.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest this evening at 08:00PM on 28/09/2023.
Areas most at risk include Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle between 07:00 PM until 9:30 PM on 28/09/2023. with the local tide level forecast to reach 1.28m.
The high tides on Friday and Saturday evening are expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
We are closely monitoring the situation remotely. We are not expecting to shut any pedestrian tide gates this evening but will monitor closely.
Consider activating any property flood protection products.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from The Rumps to Hartland Point excluding Bude
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced.  However, as we move towards the highest tides of the year this weekend, further flooding is possible with flood alerts expected to be reissued on Friday.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from Chapel Porth to The Rumps excluding the tidal River Camel
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced.  However, as we move towards the highest tides of the year this weekend, further flooding is possible with flood alerts expected to be reissued on Friday.

As a result of high spring tides, flooding of roads and farmland is possible on the high tides at 19:30 today, 28/09/23 and 07:45 tomorrow, 29/09/23. A series of high tides is due over the next 5 days. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.1m to 7.4m at 19:30 on 28/09/23 and 7.2m to 7.5m at 08:00 on 29/09/23. Newport 6.9m to 7.2m at 19:30 on 28/09/23 and 6.9m to 7.2m at 07:45 on 29/09/23.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 14:00 on 29/09/23, or as the situation changes.

As a result of strong winds and spring tides, tides will be high and may cause flooding until Monday 2nd October.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads at Fiddler’s Ferry, Eastford Road and Arpley Bridge peaking tonight between at 00:00 and 01:00 at between 6.4m to 6.7m. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. This situation is likely to repeated for every high tide from now until Monday 2nd October, with high tides coinciding with spring tides. There are two high tides a day, with the night tides being higher than the day time high tides.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated on 02/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides, tides will be at their highest overnight on 28/09/2023 at 11:30PM.
Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
With high spring tides, this situation is likely to be repeated for every high tide from now until Monday 2nd October.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 08:00 AM on 29/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Silloth to St Bees
items.message:
We do not expect the morning high tide to reach flood alert level.

We are expecting higher than normal tides over the weekend as a result of the high spring tides. It is expected that we will issue further alerts or warnings as these tides approach.

This Flood Alert was issued due to the high tide forecast at 11:00 PM on Wednesday 27/09/2023.
This alert will stay in effect through the day in anticipation of the high tide tonight at 11:45 PM on Thursday 28/09/2023. 
No property flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on Thursday 28/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

We do not expect the morning high tide to reach flood alert level.

We are expecting higher than normal tides over the weekend as a result of the high spring tides. It is expected that we will issue further alerts or warnings as these tides approach.
